BE11:14am

Britain went sport crazy yesterday and Sports Direct’s statement this morning carried on the extraordinary trend. There appears to be a number of issues that are delaying the figures (they will be released at some time between 26th July and 23rd August). Of least significance (but embarrassing nonetheless) is the fact that the finance department, and thus the auditors, seem to have been overrun by the amount of work required given the changing shape of the group. This point on management spreading itself thinly is very significant in general. It is clear that the acquisition of HOF is causing a lot of boardroom head-scratching: there seems to be major concern about current trading and a walk around the stores suggests that they are lacking some retail inspiration at the moment. The initial guidance here was for £50m of EBITDA losses this year but it could be worse than that and the bounce back to flat will surely be pushed back a long way. Department store retailing is tough, even with the best of assets.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Arguably the most alarming element of all is the last paragraph of the RNS which talks about the uncertainty in SPD’s ability to deliver the core guidance given at the interims. Given that the interims EBITDA print was decent, our suspicion is that trading in calendar 2019 has been very poor: weather patterns have been unhelpful and the “elevation” strategy may have worked for a handful of outlets but the core, untouched store portfolio remains under pressure. It surely has to be the case that group management has taken on too much here. Let’s be clear: we think Mike Ashley is a genius when it comes to sports retail. No doubt about it. However, to make an analogy, he’s trying to coach the England football team whilst running the netball, the tennis and the chess team as well. Unfortunately for him, his key lieutenants are starting to jump ship: Karen Byers, who has been instrumental in the growth of the core business, has left and that is another savage blow. We would consider that an expectations rebase for HOF as not unexpected. For the core to start showing signs of difficulties as well is of major concern. It is impossible to generate a price target given such financial uncertainty, but the shares will be pressurised today.

The ‘for tax purposes’ seems to be mis-represented as ‘coining it’. To be fair, we think there is never a good time for a company insider to sell shares – it is always damned if/when you do. While the only acceptable timing is following results (H1 results were 2 July), given the fragility of the share, and the wider market, the news this morning has had a compounding negative effect. To remind; H1 results were in line, yes there were divisional ‘puts and takes’, but Micro Focus guided for an in-line FY. We remain encouraged by (i) continued progress on reducing the cost base – down 9.5%/US$ with the FTE count now at 12,000 – rem this was 18,000 when the HPE deal was first conceived. (ii) CEO references to ongoing process improvements suggesting that FTE rightsizing may be largely played out. (iii) While financial disclosure has yet to catchup we are encouraged by the narrative of around the four ‘go to’ market propositions in Enterprise DevOps, Hybrid IT, Security, Risk and Governance and Predictive Analytics – in time these will drive ‘growth’, in our view.

Grouchmonkey morning
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Or, in longer form:

BE11:29am

Our view. The optics never look right in that it always seems the wrong time for a company director to sell shares. But in fairness, we are relaxed with the “tax purposes” reason given that Mr Loosemore retains a further c.640k shares. Investors may recall that Mr Loosemore has not sold shares since 2010 when he was financing his house purchase.
As investors appreciate, Mr Loosemore is committed to the firm and has said for many years that he will stay as Chairman for as long as shareholders would like him too. So yes, the market has ‘gulped’ at the quantum of the share sale, but we think it is a nice opportunity for someone else to pick up the stock.
This is the playbook. The company is making steady progress, delivering against financial and operational commitments, applying the Micro Focus operating model increasingly consistently across the Group, focusing on customer needs, and continuing to improve the culture to be more decisive and results-focused. This results in moderate rates of revenue decline, improved Adjusted EBITDA margins and significant levels of cash to deliver sustained and strong shareholder returns.
Investment case precis. Our view is that Micro Focus is not just a restructuring play, but that it is increasingly ‘joined-up’ as it engages customers through its four ‘go to’ market propositions in Enterprise DevOps, Hybrid IT, Security, Risk and Governance and Predictive Analytics. Important; these knit together products (remember Micro Focus has c300 products) from its individual ‘silo’ groups. The ‘field’ approach fosters improved cross- and upselling and this (as well as reducing its cost base) is how Micro Focus unlocks margin growth – in time this should also spark new growth avenues and new ‘carve-out’ opportunities like SUSE. The H1 print surfaced some weakness in software sales (a.k.a. Licence revenue - 11.1% Y/Y), but remedial actions and 161 product updates in the period suggest that Micro Focus is delivering on its promise of ‘customer centric innovation’. It is too early in the HPE integration to expect a full set of KPIs in areas like; (i) cross-selling, (ii) customer asp and life time value, (iii) maintenance renewal rates, (iv) product-based roadmaps, (v) license revenue growth, and (iv) salesforce productivity increases, which makes the restructuring a bit of a ‘black box’. Being confident of continued improving execution, we retain our Buy rating.

Alan Turing, the second world war codebreaker, has been chosen as the new face of the £50 note as the Bank of England celebrates Britain’s scientific achievements.

Mark Carney, BoE governor, announced the news at the Science and Industry Museum in Manchester. The museum houses the first computer to run a stored program, which was designed by Turing when he worked at Manchester university.

While making this programme, I was shocked to learn that many large house-builders won’t allow buyers to hire an independent surveyor before they complete the purchase. “It’s a problem across the industry,” says chartered surveyor Greig Adams. “If you try to get a survey done before you move in, most of [the big house-builders] will block it”.

So consumers enjoy more protection buying a toaster than when they buy a new-build home, probably the biggest purchase of their life.

The Telegraph reported over the weekend that a Channel 4 documentary (Dispatches) to be shown tonight highlights quality issues at some Persimmon homes. However, these issues are likely to be historic and new CEO, Dave Jenkinson (in place since November 2018) has made resolving quality problems his top priority; and The Telegraph has reported that Persimmon has fully apologised for its lapses. Any weakness, either today or tomorrow should be seen as a buying opportunity. We are convinced that quality will be improved at relatively low cost, and that prospective buyers are unlikely to be unduly concerned (far worse issues were quickly forgotten at Bovis). The shares have underperformed large cap peers (Barratt and Taylor Wimpey) by over 25% this year, and we see this as undeserved. Persimmon's shares trade at 7.1 cal19E PER and yield 12%.

BE11:48am

This is optically a significant figure, and one that has taken us by surprise
as Reko Diq, given legal wrangling, had fallen away from the markets’ focus in recent years. On an attributable share and fully un-risked, the settlement is equivalent to ~£2.30/sh, or ~40% our base case ANTO valuation. But Pakistan’s financial situation is precarious, highlighted by its dependence on an IMF rescue package earlier this year, so its ability to service the award (in full and in a timely manner) is highly questionable. As such, we expect the headline figure should be heavily risked. Furthermore, whilst the award is binding we understand there still remain legal avenues for the government to appeal the procedural process. We currently attribute no value for Reko Diq in our base case valuation and we note as yet ANTO will not recognise the expected proceeds in its financial statements. We have an UW recommendation on ANTO.

red we even set the admin charged.
BE11:49am

Reko Diq arbitration award: International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (“ICSID”) has awarded $5.84bn in damages to Tethyan Copper Company Pty Limited (“TCC”). TSS is a 50:50 JV between Antofagasta and Barrick Gold (covered by US Analyst John Bridges) which owns a 75% interest in the Reko Diq copper project in Pakistan. The claims are in relation to arbitration filed against the Islamic Republic of Pakistan to the unlawful denial of a mining lease. The claim comprises (100% basis): (i) $4.087bn in compensation by reference to the fair market value of the project at the time of the mining lease denial; and (ii) interest of $1.753bn until the date of the award. There is a further $62m for costs incurred by claimants.
 Next steps: The award is binding, but we understand there still remain legal avenues for the government to appeal the procedural process. We understand previous challenges have typically had up to 120 days to appeal (although we are unsure whether this applies to the current process). ANTO also noted in the release that they “remain willing to discuss the potential for a negotiated settlement…”; given the interest is housed within TCC it is unclear whether a settlement requires the approval of both parties (i.e. ANTO and ABX) or whether either party can reach a settlement / outcome individually (either with the government or with a 3rd party).
 Valuation impact: On an attributable ANTO share and fully un-risked, the settlement is equivalent to ~£2.30/sh, or ~40% our base case valuation. However we identify elevated risks around the settlement being received (ANTO itself does not yet include the proceeds in its financial statements). We believe the market will likely factor in a small fraction of the total amount, if any, until there is more clarity on the legal avenues remaining to the government, source of its funding and timeframe. To put into context, a 25% risk-weighting would be ~10% of our base case valuation. We attribute no value for Reko Diq in our base case valuation.

BE11:50am

According to Antofagasta, a JV held by the company and Barrick - Tethyan Copper Company (TCC) - has been awarded US$5.84bn in damages by the World Bank arbitration court, to be paid by Pakistan following the 'unlawful denial of a mining lease for the Reko Diq project in 2011'. The ruling came after 7 years of arbitration. Tethyan has a 75% interest in the Reko Diq copper project and is equally/jointly owned by Antofagasta and Barrick.Although the outcome is in favour of Antofagasta and should - in theory - result in a material windfall gain, we note that recovery of the awarded amount is uncertain. Antofagasta has stated that proceeds of the award will not be recognized in its financial statements until received. TCC states that it remains “willing to discuss the potential for a negotiated settlement with Pakistan and will continue to protect its commercial interests and legal rights until the conclusion of the dispute". We currently assign no value to Reko Diq in our base or bull cases and calculate that a recovery of the full attributable amount could translate into a value of up to US$2.9bn or GBp 233/share.

The proposed disposal of Manufacturing for a cash consideration in excess of Swallowfield’s market cap should allow the Group to solely focus on its Owned Brands business which, over time, should allow the company to generate stronger growth at better margins, with less capital and lower earnings volatility. In the near term, however, progress may be held back by the weaker retail environment but the medium to longerterm growth opportunities remain as compelling as ever in our view.

FATDAZ @excel thanks for the link
BE12:00pm

Swallowfield has entered into a conditional agreement with Knowlton Development Corporation (KDC), North America’s largest custom formulator and manufacturer serving the prestige beauty, personal care and household sectors, to sell its manufacturing business for a cash consideration of £35m, subject to adjustment for working capital at the date of completion. The deal will require shareholder approval at a general meeting on 31 July 2019. The Group also proposes to change its name to Brand Architekts Group upon completion of the deal. Matthew Gazzard (Group Finance Director) and Jane Fletcher (Group Marketing and Sales Director) intend to transfer with the manufacturing business and will therefore leave the group. Following the disposal, the Group should have net cash of c.£23m (after deductions and expenses of the transaction), allowing it to drive future growth both organically and by acquisition.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Brand Architekts Group

fortyeight Land and property is already subject to Income Tax, Corporation Tax, Capital Gains Tax, VAT, Inheritance Tax, Stamp Duty on sale, Stamp Duty on letting, Section 106, CIL, Insurance Premium tax, Business rates, Council tax.
BE12:01pm

Trading update
The Group has traded broadly in line with expectations for the full year to June 2019. Group revenues rose 7% against the prior 52 weeks (+5% on the reported 53-week basis), with a 3% decline in Owned Brands (on a 52-week basis) offset by an 8% growth in Manufacturing (52 weeks). The weakness in Brands reflects lower consumer confidence in the UK and pressures within the retail environment, which resulted in a softening in demand and reductions in category space and promotions. Good progress continues to be made in international sales of the Brands business, up 8%, while divisional gross margins were maintained. Group net debt was £7.3m as at 29 June 2019.

BE12:10pm

We view the positive headline results from the PRIMA study as a positive meaning that Zejula could be the first PARP inhibitor approved in the front line non-BRCA ovarian cancer setting, significantly expanding the target ovarian cancer population which is currently restricted to patients with germline BRCA mutation (c.15% of ovarian cancers).

BE12:11pm

For context, AZN-MRK’s Lynparza approval in the front line ovarian cancer setting on the back of SOLO-1 is restricted to patients with the BRCA mutation.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Aside from ovarian cancer, Zejula is also being trialled in combination with other agents [their own PD-1 inhibitor] as well as in other tumor types such as breast cancer and prostate cancer [partnered with JNJ], which could provide long term upside opportunity.
We note that the ultimate commercial potential on the frontline for Zejula will be dependent on the strength of the data from this study, buy also on the readout from AZN’s PAOLA-1 study (which combines their PARP inhibitor Lynparza with Avastin in the frontline setting and which is expected to readout 2H19). At present, consensus estimates (company-compiled) for Zejula stand at c.£250mn (c.2% of pharma sales), with peak sales potential of c.£800mn by 2023 (c.4% of pharma sales).

BE12:13pm

The commercial implications of this result will only fully become clear when the magnitude of the benefit in important subgroups (gBRCA, non-gBRCA HRD+, and non-gBRCA HRD- patients) is revealed at an upcoming medical conference. We currently forecast peak sales of $550m in 1st line OC maintenance, at 80% probability of success, and $300m combined in 2nd line OC maintenance and greater than 4th line OC treatment, reflecting the competitive OC treatment paradigm.

12:13 pm
BE12:13pm

Significant opportunity beyond BRCA: AZN's PARP inhibitor Lynparza is currently used as first-line maintenance therapy after demonstrating remarkable efficacy in OC patients with germline BRCA mutations (gBRCAm). GSK estimates that c.300,000 women are diagnosed with OC every year and the most significant opportunity for GSK lies in the c.35% of OC patients that have non-gBRCA homologous recombination deficiencies. These patients are the most likely to benefit from treatment with a PARP inhibitor, outside of gBRCAm patients, and Zejula could become the first PARP inhibitor to demonstrate a clinically meaningful benefit in this group. We note data from the ongoing PAOLA-1 study evaluating Lynparza +Avastin in first-line maintenance treatment of “all-comers” are also expected in 2H19E. Even if PAOLA-1 is positive, GSK is confident Zejula could be “best-in-class”, with its once-daily dosing (vs. Lynparza twice daily), improved side effect burden with weight- and platelet-adjusted dosing, and potential for monotherapy efficacy, capturing share in the first-line maintenance OC setting.

BE12:13pm

Zejula a key component of the Tesaro acquisition: We see the strategic rationale for the Dec 2018 £4bn Tesaro acquisition: providing an oncology footprint in S&M, regulatory affairs, and further R&D expertise. At the time, the deal consideration raised concerns given Zejula’s current positioning in the competitive PARP inhibitor space, however GSK cited its confidence that PRIMA data could demonstrate that Zejula is best-in-class, capturing share in this larger patient population, almost 2x 2nd line, and where treatment durations are longer, whilst upcoming combination data could help expand use into other tumour types. Upcoming readouts include, Phase II JASPER data +/- TSR-042 (PD-1) in first-line NSCLC during 2H19E and Phase II OVARIO data +Avastin in first-line maintenance for OC around YE19E.
